results.title: Melbourne (no. 1)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Brief shots of the Shrine of Rememberance.

Section 2. Shots of the 1848 building from several angles.

Section 3. A cricket match at the MCG. Sparse crowd. Several angles and shots, lasts for three minutes.

Section 4. Luna Park at night. Brief shot of the entrance and the exterior of a dogem cars attraction.

Section 5. Houses in Melbourne; older and ‘new’. Brief.

Section 6. Various shots of parks and gardens. Brief.

Section 7. Spencer Street rail yards, shot from above. Brief.

Section 8. A few shots of the city, including trams and St. Paul’s cathederal.

Section 9. Woman in a park, admiring a flower bed. Good close-ups.

Section 10. Camera pans up from the Yarra to St Paul’s Cathederal/city in the distance. Nice shot.

Section 11. Good shots of the city from the Yarra.

results.title: If Wes Anderson made a movie in Ukraine
results.material_description: Screen recording of @Valerisssh’s TikTok post 'If Wes Anderson made a movie in Ukraine'
results.title_for_label: If Wes Anderson made a movie in Ukraine
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

From bold colours and carefully composed frames to his trademark symmetry, Wes Anderson’s films are instantly recogniseable – and easily imitated. Social media users across the world have mimicked his techniques to put a whimsical lens on their cities. With over 326,000 likes and 1178 comments, this one stands out. By marrying Anderson’s playfulness with the seriousness of war, Ukrainian activist Valeria Shashenok uses social media and a smartphone to counter media narratives of a war-torn country and proves that creativity can’t be defeated.
description_for_label: From bold colours and carefully composed frames to his trademark symmetry, Wes Anderson’s films are instantly recogniseable – and easily imitated. Social media users across the world have mimicked his techniques to put a whimsical lens on their cities. With over 326,000 likes and 1178 comments, this one stands out. By marrying Anderson’s playfulness with the seriousness of war, Ukrainian activist Valeria Shashenok uses social media and a smartphone to counter media narratives of a war-torn country and proves that creativity can’t be defeated.

results.title: Mongolian Princess costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description:
From seller: A Mongolian Princess costume worn in the 1987 multi Oscar-winning drama The Last Emperor. This stunning costume was worn when the 15 year-old Pu-Yi (Wu Tao) wed’s the ‘old’ government chosen first wife and Empress, 17-year old Wan Jung.
The multi-layered costume consists of a thick white quilted gown with ties to the front, a red rayon brocade under robe overprinted in gold with panels in mulberry green and gold appliqué, high padded shoulders, tall collars, and cuffs trimmed in grey Astrakhan and Mongolian lambswool, and finally a waistcoat in maroon velvet and green brocade, overprinted in gold trimmed with antique fabric appliqués on the front and back panels. There are no sizes marked on this wonderful costume and it remains in excellent condition.
This comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Stories and songs of the people: they came for gathering
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, Johnnie Aseron, Indigenous Unit, AFC, ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit and f-reel
results.brief_description: This video documents the first ‘Stories and songs of the people’ event held in Australia at the Forum theatre, Melbourne in 1999. This event was organised by “grass roots” community and gave the opportunity for many artists to express a collective future through music. It’s aim was to create a cultural and educational exchange with other First Nations groups from around the globe. bearing in mind similarities which exist between some Indigenous peoples, eg American and Australian First Nations colonisation and dispossession, their traditional links to the land and the loss of their identity. Music is seen as a healing process towards reconciliation. Performing artists include Frankie Yamma, Peter Rotumah, Deb Morrow, Kelli Howell, Neil Murray & Stephen Teakle, Shane Howard, Illana Atkinson, Tom E. Lewis, Tiffany Eckardt & Dave Steel, Nick larkins, Lee Morgan, Russell Smith, Malcolm Jagamuarra and visiting Native American artist Johnnie Aseron. Video support notes included.

results.title: Sacred sites
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza narrates this exploration of Australian First Nations people’s relationship to sacred sites. Several sites are visited with their guardians who explain the importance of maintaining the sites and protecting them from the tourist, mining and agricultural industries. Sites visited include, Merella Cave, W.A., Uluru, Alice Springs, Guru Guru Cave, W.A. and Milbrodale, N.S.W. There are also extensive interviews with Charles Perkins.

results.title: Cherish
results.creator_credit: Romaine Moreton, Stephen Jones and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
“What peace is there for us whose best love cannot return them even for a day? …..The last word was yours.” (Jeannette Winterson ‘Written on the Body’)
A poetic and tender story celebrating life, love and death.
Cast: John Adam, Russell Page

results.title: The Cup and the lip
results.creator_credit: Joanna Robinski, Bruno de Villenoisy and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A difficult child and a good mother. A loose tooth, a sign on a wall, an imaginary word, ecstasy, anger… A disturbing film about the ultimate taboo.
Cast: Gosia Dobrowolska, Julian Barta

results.title: The Good Fight
results.creator_credit: Citt Williams, Beck Cole and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
The good fight is a documentary film about masculinity in a modern world, spirituality and the lore of the boxing ring. Set in Dulwich Hill, Sydney’s inner west, the film delves into the gritty existence of a local ‘Fight Club’ led by an unlikely character, Rev. Dave Smith. The story evolves around Rev. Dave’s relationships with the young people who frequent the Fight Club. Includes interviews with Jared Tekaki, Craig (Shorty) Sutton, Shaun Joyce and Alex Tui.
Contains some b&w images.
results.description:
The good fight is a documentary film about masculinity in a modern world, spirituality and the lore of the boxing ring. Set in Dulwich Hill, Sydney’s inner west, the film delves into the gritty existence of a local ‘Fight Club’ led by an unlikely character, Rev. Dave Smith. The story evolves around Rev. Dave’s relationships with the young people who frequent the Fight Club. Includes interviews with Jared Tekaki, Craig (Shorty) Sutton, Shaun Joyce and Alex Tui.
Contains some b&w images.

results.title: Louise
results.creator_credit: Kelly Schilling, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short documentary about a woman named Louise Mitchie who was born as a replacement child - a child conceived and born in order to help with the grief experienced by parents who had lost their first child in infancy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kelly Schilling, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS
